stream_context.summary: Kaze iterates on a late-game/section mechanic where hitting targets triggers a moving glow line and ultimately blows the “cap” off a structure so Mario can enter. He replaces an older chase segment he disliked, tunes difficulty and collision so players can’t get unfairly crushed, fixes spline/trig and sound bugs, and begins implementing a star-gated entrance guarded by a custom Thwomp NPC. Mid-stream he discusses community backlash to a Teemu sponsorship, his stance on generative AI, and (most notably) a plan to publish an engine-only repository before RTYI’s public release to solicit bug fixes and help scrub any remaining Nintendo code—plus a tentative, lawyer-dependent idea of a fully custom-IP PC/Steam port.
stream_context.significance_reason: Introduces a concrete pre-release strategy: shipping an engine-only repo (with game content removed) to get community testing and help ensure no Nintendo code remains, and floats a lawyer-dependent custom-IP PC/Steam port. Also shows substantial redesign of a disliked chase segment and implementation of a star-gated Thwomp guard with cutscene logic.

findings.summary: He is rebuilding a sequence where hitting targets triggers a moving glow/line and then blows the cap off a structure, allowing entry; he shows an early tutorial target followed by three shooters that fire bullets, ending the section once all are hit.
He explicitly replaces an older “snuffer chase” because he thought it played badly, while keeping an “upside-down flying” part in the final build but intending to polish it.
findings.quote: This is because the old snuffer chase was ass.

findings.summary: To prevent frustrating deaths, he explores solutions to Mario getting under the cap mechanism and being crushed; he leans toward altering the geometry/collision so the player simply cannot stand underneath, framing it as a cleaner on/off interaction.
findings.quote: We need the solution for when Mario gets under the thing… It’s too easy to get crushed. … I think this is the play. Because that way it’s like an on-off thing.

findings.summary: He debugs spline/curve behavior and projectile/path math, discovering incorrect spline type and trigonometry (needing cosine), plus state-setting issues (e.g., not setting a halt flag) that affected visual behavior like sparkles and animation timing.
He tracks down an audio behavior issue (sound not fading/muting as expected) to a BPM-related value being set to 0 instead of the expected ~12, restoring correct behavior once corrected.
findings.quote: Wait, BPM4 is zero? I’m pretty sure LSG told me it was 12… Why was this set to zero?

findings.summary: He notes input-feature tradeoffs: D-pad is currently reserved for debug functions, but he expects D-pad movement to be in the final build; he also says he hasn’t implemented rumble support because he doesn’t own a Rumble Pak to test with.
He remarks that the team is “almost done with section 8,” implying this chunk of the game is nearing completion pending polish and bug fixes.
findings.quote: Dude, we’re almost done with section 8 now. That’s cool.

findings.summary: He begins implementing a star-gated entrance to a Bowser-minion-restricted area/level: a custom Thwomp guard blocks the path, requires mandatory dialogue, checks for ~30 stars, then triggers a cutscene where the guard moves aside permanently.
findings.quote: Once you have enough stars and you talk to him, there’s gonna be a cutscene of him walking out. And then you can enter the level for the rest of your life.

findings.summary: He worries about running out of N64 RAM due to earlier “silly” choices, even though he believes he could have saved memory with stricter discipline—suggesting active memory-budget pressure as content expands.
findings.quote: I’m kind of just worried about running out of RAM. That’s honestly my worry right now.

findings.summary: He proposes an engine-only pre-release: finish engine rewrites first, remove all RTYI game content from the repository, and publish only the engine with a minimal test map so others can find improvements/bug fixes and help identify/remove any remaining Nintendo code before the game’s first public release.
findings.quote: I’m gonna finish all my engine rewrites… then I’ll remove all the game content from the repository and release only the engine… so that way we can improve the engine even more before the first public release of the game.

findings.summary: He floats a lawyer-dependent plan to create a PC port with a completely custom IP (no Mario, no Nintendo code, fully custom moveset) and possibly release it on Steam; he expresses fear about the legal risk and frames it explicitly as contingent on professional legal advice.
findings.quote: The custom version would be no Nintendo code, not even Mario… I would definitely have to talk to a lawyer about it beforehand.

findings.summary: He states he does not use generative AI for RTYI and does not plan to, citing both ethical/community backlash concerns and the belief that it offers little practical benefit to the project’s needs right now.
findings.quote: I know people hate gen AI. And just because of that, I am not going to use it in my game.

findings.summary: While discussing tuning/physics, he articulates a broader creative principle: too much friction reduction or over-optimization can hollow out the ‘purpose and soul’ of the game, turning it into ‘slop,’ implying a deliberate effort to preserve a specific feel even when modernizing Mario 64 movement.
findings.quote: There comes a point at which you reduce friction so much that you lose the game’s purpose and soul. And it just turns into slop.

findings.summary: He mentions wrist pain and general fatigue (week feeling unusually long), which may be impacting pace and comfort during long implementation/debug sessions.
findings.quote: I don’t know what’s going on with my wrist. I fucked it up somehow.

biobak.summary: Kaze tells Biobak a separate project (not detailed on-stream) is starting “phase 1” tomorrow, and he aims to bring Biobak in around mid-January once foundational work is done before involving artists.
biobak.quote: It is going to start phase 1 tomorrow… mid-January I’m gonna try to bring you on… we have a lot of stuff to do before any artist can be on the project.

biobak.summary: Biobak pings Kaze repeatedly during the stream (Kaze reacts jokingly/irritated), illustrating the ongoing real-time collaboration dynamic via chat even when not formally reviewing assets.

zeina.summary: Kaze references playing Yoshi’s Woolly World in multiplayer with Zeina and finding the co-op camera/screen tether frustrating because the slower player can halt progress, offering a glimpse into how the couple experiences and critiques platformer design together.
zeina.quote: It sucks for both players… Basically just cripple each other in multiplayer.

findings.summary: Kaze answers a community ‘romhack of the year’ poll live, using it as an opportunity to compare hacks and remark that RTYI is not in the poll because it would be ‘not a fair competition,’ and that they already won ‘most anticipated’ previously.
findings.quote: They don’t put RTYI on this because they know we just win.

memorable_quotes.speaker: Kaze
memorable_quotes.quote: I’m gonna finish all my engine rewrites… then I’ll remove all the game content from the repository and release only the engine.
memorable_quotes.context: A concrete, documentary-relevant plan: separating engine tech from Nintendo-branded/game content for external review, improvement, and legal hygiene before release.

memorable_quotes.speaker: Kaze
memorable_quotes.quote: There comes a point at which you reduce friction so much that you lose the game’s purpose and soul. And it just turns into slop.
memorable_quotes.context: Captures his design philosophy about modernizing Mario 64 while preserving a specific feel—central to ‘respectful reinvention’.

memorable_quotes.speaker: Kaze
memorable_quotes.quote: The custom version would be no Nintendo code, not even Mario… I would definitely have to talk to a lawyer about it beforehand.
memorable_quotes.context: Shows the boundary between creative ambition and legal fear; introduces the Steam/custom-IP idea as conditional on legal advice.

key_stories.title: Replacing the snuffer chase with a target-shooting/cap-blowoff sequence
key_stories.summary: Kaze shows an in-progress rebuild of a section: a tutorial target followed by multiple enemies that shoot at the player, culminating in a visual line effect and a cap that flies off to open progression. He frames the rebuild as a direct response to dissatisfaction with the previous chase design.
key_stories.challenge: The prior ‘snuffer chase’ sequence felt bad to play and wasn’t meeting his quality bar.
key_stories.process: Prototype a new encounter structure (tutorial → three shooters), iterate on timings, visuals (glow line), and gating (cap removal), and plan additional polish for an upside-down flying segment that will remain in the final game.
key_stories.outcome: New structure is working in early form but still needs tuning, bug fixes, and polish; it replaces the old chase in the intended final experience.
key_stories.key_quote: This is because the old snuffer chase was ass.

key_stories.title: Engine-only release as a pre-release QA and legal hygiene step
key_stories.summary: Kaze proposes publishing only the RTYI engine (with game content removed) after finishing major engine rewrites. The goal is to let others dissect the tech, contribute bug fixes, and help identify any remaining Nintendo code before the game’s first public release.
key_stories.challenge: He wants broader testing and improvement of the engine while minimizing legal exposure from distributing Nintendo-derived content.
key_stories.process: Finish engine rewrites; strip game content from the repo; ship a minimal test map; invite community to find improvements/bugs and help scrub lingering Nintendo code; then fold improvements back before public game release.
key_stories.outcome: Chat responds positively, and Kaze frames it as a sensible next step; details (timing, license, contribution workflow) remain undecided.
key_stories.key_quote: …release only the engine… and maybe help remove any remaining Nintendo code that I may have missed.

key_stories.title: The PewDiePie ROM hack commission and creator-centric hacks
key_stories.summary: Kaze recounts being paid in 2017 to create a PewDiePie-themed ROM hack during the ‘subscribe to PewDiePie’ era. He built a level based on the ‘bridge incident,’ making the player defeat enemies before a censored clip would play, and uses the story to explain why he dislikes hacks that revolve around a single content creator unless they are satirical.
key_stories.challenge: Navigating commission work tied to internet culture and controversies, while developing a personal stance on what kinds of ROM hacks feel creatively ‘cringe.’
key_stories.process: Accepted the commission, designed a concept-level with a timed objective, and incorporated censorship/satire; later reflects on the broader cultural context and how his views were out of step with mainstream creator culture at the time.
key_stories.outcome: He cites it as an example of a creator-focused hack he still considers ‘peak,’ while reiterating his dislike of non-satirical creator worship hacks.
key_stories.key_quote: I hate when ROM hackers just make hacks that are so focused on one content creator. I think it’s ultra cringe.

open_questions.topic: Engine-only repository release (scope, workflow, and legal posture)
open_questions.context: Kaze wants to publish RTYI’s engine with all game content removed, plus a minimal test map, to solicit bug fixes and help ensure no Nintendo code remains before the first public RTYI release.
questions: What exact boundary will define ‘engine’ vs ‘game content’ (assets, scripts, level formats, text, animations, tools)?
How will you verify the repo is free of Nintendo code—manual audit, tooling, third-party review, or a defined checklist?
What license/contribution policy would you use to accept community fixes while keeping the project shippable (CLA, contributor agreements, etc.)?
When in the timeline would this happen relative to the next demo/public milestone, and what would qualify as ‘engine rewrites finished’?

open_questions.context: Kaze mentions a potentially separate PC port with no Nintendo code and no Mario (fully custom character and moveset), but he is ‘afraid’ and would consult a lawyer; outcome is framed as binary based on legal advice.
questions: What parts of RTYI tech/content would carry over into a custom-IP port (engine, physics philosophy, level concepts), and what must be rebuilt from scratch to stay safe?
What is the minimum ‘customness’ threshold you’d aim for (movement, camera, character silhouette, level motifs) to feel legally and creatively distinct?
What is the specific legal risk you’re most worried about—copyright, trademark, trade dress, or DMCA/takedown history?
If a lawyer said ‘yes,’ would this become the primary release vehicle, a parallel product, or a post-RTYI project?

open_questions.topic: Star-gated Thwomp guard and progression pacing
open_questions.context: Kaze starts implementing a custom Thwomp NPC that blocks entry to a Bowser-minions area and moves away permanently after mandatory dialogue and a ~30-star requirement; he also mentions current total puzzle stars being around ~65.
questions: How did you choose 30 stars as the gate—what pacing/skill assumptions does that represent, and how does it map to your intended difficulty curve?
What information will the guard communicate (lore, tutorializing progression, hinting at what’s beyond), and how do you avoid it feeling like an arbitrary lock?
Is the ‘permanent unlock after cutscene’ meant to encourage revisits, speedrunning, or reduce repeat friction—and how will that interact with completionist routes?

open_questions.topic: N64 RAM pressure and content priorities
open_questions.context: Kaze says he’s worried about running out of RAM and attributes it partly to earlier ‘silly’ choices; he dismisses expansion-pack talk as a recurring community meme but acknowledges the constant pressure.
questions: What are the top current RAM consumers in RTYI (textures, geometry, animations, audio banks, scripting data), and which are hardest to reduce without sacrificing identity?
What ‘silly things’ do you regret memory-wise, and what concrete memory-budget rules (if any) are you adopting now?
Are there specific levels/features at risk of being cut or redesigned purely for memory reasons—and how do you decide what stays to keep the game ‘respectful’ but new?
